verses.text: Then the righteous will stand with great confidence before those who oppressed them and those who made light of their labors.
verses.comment: The scene points to final vindication at the judgment, echoing Psalm 1 and Christ’s Sermon on the Mount, which assures endurance leads to true glory.

verses.text: When the wicked see them, they will be shaken with terrible fear, amazed at how unexpectedly the saved ones are rescued.
verses.comment: The reaction of the wicked is utter shock and fear, reflecting the reversal of fortunes foretold throughout Scripture.

verses.text: They will speak among themselves, filled with regret and groaning in distress of spirit:
verses.comment: The internal remorse highlights the everlasting consequences of the choices made in life, consistent with the spiritual teachings on judgment.

verses.text: ‘These are the people whom we once held in derision and as a joke—their lives seemed to us foolish, and their end disgraceful.
verses.comment: This verse mirrors the mockery endured by the righteous, notably Christ. Their suffering is revealed to have led to eternal glory—a powerful spiritual theme.

verses.text: How is it that they are now counted among the children of God, and their lot with the holy ones?
verses.comment: Union with God’s people emphasizes the familial relationship echoed in the New Testament, with the concept of sanctification—a process revealed in tradition and sacrament.

verses.text: So it was we who strayed from the path of truth; the light of righteousness did not shine for us, nor did the sun rise upon us.
verses.comment: The imagery of missing the true light calls back to Christ as the Light of the World, underscoring the necessity of walking faithfully.

verses.text: We wandered through paths of wickedness and ruin, traveled through deserts without the way, but we did not know the road of the Lord.
verses.comment: Spiritual lostness is compared to being outside the covenant and guidance provided by the true faith, including the teaching office of the Church.

verses.text: What good did our pride and wealth bring us? All our boasting brought us nothing.
verses.comment: Material riches and pride are shown to be empty in the face of eternal reality, echoing Jesus' teachings about the dangers of wealth.

verses.text: All these things have passed away like a shadow, like a rumor that goes by;
verses.comment: Temporal things are fleeting, underscoring the soul’s primacy over material pursuits and the need for divine grace to persevere.

verses.text: Like a ship passing through the waves, and the trace of its passage cannot be found, nor the path of its keel in the waters.
verses.comment: This image reveals the fleeting nature of earthly life, a reminder of the call to seek that which endures—faith, hope, and charity.

verses.text: Or like a bird flying through the air, no sign of its journey is found—the air is pressed as it moves, but then instantly closed after the way is gone.
verses.comment: The brevity of life is emphasized, consistent with Psalm 90’s teaching. Spiritual treasures are the true, lasting legacy.

verses.text: Or like an arrow shot at a target—the pierced air closes up at once, so that none knows the path it took.
verses.comment: Labor and effort are quickly forgotten, but what remains is virtue—attainable only by grace and perseverance.

verses.text: So we also, as soon as we were born, ceased to exist, and had no sign of virtue to show, but were consumed in our wickedness.
verses.comment: The absence of virtue reflects the necessity of grace and transformation, as taught throughout the apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Because the hope of the ungodly is like chaff blown by the wind, like light foam carried off by the storm, vanishing like smoke with the wind, and passing away like a memory of a single day.
verses.comment: The foundation of hope for the unfaithful is compared to chaff—worthless and fleeting—emphasizing the need for true spiritual grounding.

verses.text: But the righteous live forever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.
verses.comment: Eternal life and reward are themes developed by Jesus and Paul, confirming the hope offered to the faithful.

verses.text: Therefore, they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the Lord’s hand, because with His right hand He will cover them, and with His arm He will protect them.
verses.comment: The crown and diadem suggest the reward of those who persevere and are sanctified, evidencing both literal and spiritual victory.

verses.text: He will take His zeal as armor, and arm creation to punish His enemies.
verses.comment: God’s zeal appears as protective and just, connecting to the messianic prophecies of divine judgment.

verses.text: He will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and true judgment as a helmet.
verses.comment: The divine armor language prefigures Paul’s teaching on spiritual armor, affirming that God equips the faithful for battle against sin.

verses.text: He will take holiness as an invincible shield,
verses.comment: Holiness is the true protection—suggesting both outer and inner sanctity, a central theme in the call to perseverance.

verses.text: He will sharpen His wrath for a sword, and creation will join Him in fighting against the lawless.
verses.comment: God’s justice is revealed as active and complete, with all creation subject to His authority—echoing numerous passages about final judgment.

verses.text: Arrows of lightning will fly with accuracy, and clouds will serve as a bow; His wrath will hurl hailstones full of fury.
verses.comment: The apocalyptic images recall divine interventions found throughout the Psalms and Prophets, revealing God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: Water will overflow and rage against them, and the rivers will drown them without mercy; a mighty wind will rise up against them as if a storm, and blow them away like dust.
verses.comment: Nature itself executes divine justice, with echoes from the Hebrew Scriptures—highlighting the harmony of creation with God’s plan.

verses.text: Thus, wickedness will lay waste all the earth, and evil-doers will meet their end in fire.
verses.comment: Final destruction by fire is a strong motif of judgment, connecting to the teachings of Jesus about the ultimate fate of those outside God's grace. The passage closes with an appeal to repentance, ongoing conversion, and perseverance in grace—core themes of apostolic faith.
